Comment: Hydrogen fuel cell cars have about 2kg of gaseous hydrogen in a reinforced carbon fiber tank. The tank itself is the strongest part of the car and, in testing, safely vented all its gas and survived in one piece while the rest of the car was a pancake, simulating a fatal accident. Hydrogen is thermodynamically weird because it gets hot when you compress AND expand it, so the fuel is chilled to super low temps before being charged into the car at 700 bar. It goes in cold but does acclimate to room temperature. It doesn't need to be stored cryogenically because it's a gas. That gets them about the same distance as the average gasoline sedan. I have bottles of hydrogen sitting in a shop at room temperature that have not lost any pressure in 3 years. Fuel cell cars should never lose pressure at rest, and they have sensors to detect if there is an unknown loss of fuel.    But cars are not the only or even best use of the fuel. Long term energy storage from excess green energy can be stored virtually indefinitely, and the tanks and fuel cells are far easier to manufacturer and replace than large scale battery farms. It can even be used like a burnable fuel if fuel cells aren't available. It has the potential to solve every problem that green energy sources have with reliable generation, as well as create a new form of power reserve for emergencies. Some experimental cell towers use hydrogen fuel backup generators. The benefits of the fuel make it more efficient, even when considering the extra generation cost in some scenarios.   The only limit on how long Hydrogen can be stored is the rehydro date on the tank (service date), and that can be 10-15 years. That's with zero energy input to maintain it; the tank just sits there. I think you're thinking of liquid nitrogen that cannot be safely contained as a liquid at room temperature without venting to keep the bulk temperature low. Our tanks will lose anywhere from 1-3% of total LIN volume daily from this process, but it can be improved with better insulation and seals
